title: Will Boris Johnson's Brexit deal pass in the Commons? How MP numbers stack up
text:

Boris Johnson this morning declared there was “white smoke” from Brussels and he and EU negotiators had come to an agreement on a deal.

But that’s only step one.

Next he has to get all 27 EU leaders to sign off on it by close of play on Friday, during what is sure to be an intense 48-hour summit in Brussels.

And then comes the really difficult bit - convincing enough MPs back home to vote it through.

That’s something Theresa May historically failed to do on three occasions.

So how do the numbers stack up - and what are the key figures who could swing it saying this morning?

Here’s what we know.

The numbers

(Image: REUTERS)

After subtracting the MPs who don’t vote - chiefly Sinn Fein and the deputy speakers - Johnson needs to convince 320 MPs to vote for his deal.

If every Conservative MP who is able to vote also backs the deal, this gives the Government 285 votes.

The most Theresa May ever managed was 279 - and she hadn’t just effectively sacked a bunch of her MPs for disloyalty.

Theoretically there are 10 DUP MPs and 21 former Tory MPs up for grabs.

Plus there’s a few Brexit-backing Labour MPs on the playing field.

But it’s still quite a mountain to climb.

The DUP

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

The DUP said in a statement that their 10 MPs would not back the PM’s deal.

They said: "Following confirmation from the Prime Minister that he believes he has secured a "great new deal" with the European Union the Democratic Unionist Party will be unable to support these proposals in Parliament.

"The Democratic Unionist Party has worked since the referendum result to secure a negotiated deal as we leave the European Union. We have been consistent that we will only ever consider supporting arrangements that are in Northern Ireland's long-term economic and constitutional interests and protect the integrity of the Union."

If they voted against, his magic number goes up to 330 - but they might not go that far. If they abtstain, it lowers the threshold for victory - but he will need to claw back those votes somewhere else.

On top of that, it’s worth bearing in mind that a lot of the hard Brexiteer MPs that make up his 285-vote baseline will take their cues from the DUP on whether they will back the deal.

Former Tories

(Image: Getty Images)

In total there are 20 ex-Tory MPs that have had the whip removed for rebelling against the PM. With Amber Rudd, who resigned the whip over Brexit , and you’ve got 21.

Not all of these are hard-bitten retainers. A lot of them want a deal, and voted for Theresa May’s deal back in March. It’s possible a chunk of them could swing behind the government on Saturday - especially if the carrot of having the whip restored is dangled in front of them.

It’s understood at least some of the awkward Tories will be meeting with Number 10 later today.

And at least one - Stephen Hammond - has said this morning that he's minded to vote for Johnson's deal.

Plus you’ve got Charlie Elphicke, who is currently sitting as an Independent after having the Conservative whip removed. He could be helpful to Johnson.

Labour Brexiteers

(Image: REUTERS)

In reality, it is unlikely all of the 21 former Conservatives would support a Withdrawal Agreement - but up to about a dozen Labour backbenchers could support a deal.

They include Kate Hoey and Kevin Barron, both of whom have said they are standing down at the next general election .

Others may abstain, lowering the threshold for a Government victory.
description: The Prime Minister's deal still has a number of hurdles to jump. Here's how many MPs he needs to convince, and what they might do
